thanks

Are there any microdata vocabularies besides schema.org? I know there are a bunch for rdfa (dublin core, creativecommons, DOAP, FOAF, etc) but I don't know of any schema.org alternatives for microdata.

* Are there any microdata vocabularies besides schema.org? I know there are a bunch for rdfa (dublin core, creativecommons, DOAP, FOAF, etc) but I don't know of any schema.org alternatives for microdata.

m.new_content.body: Are there any microdata vocabularies besides schema.org? I know there are a bunch for rdfa (dublin core, creativecommons, DOAP, FOAF, etc) but I don't know of any schema.org alternatives for microdata.

content.body: yes it does

I noticed microformats.org/profile/hcard but I don't see a point in using those over classes because classes have more universal support.

I do like schema.org's more detailed info. i would use rdfa so i could make use of dublin core, foaf, etc. but microdata has more support than rdfa (used by readability, chromium DOM distiller, less error prone on search engines, and some others). which is why I ask.

Mixing microformats classnamwa and microdata syntax is okay but dealing with a third format kinda kills the fun of structured data for me.

content.body: I know it's possible to create ad-hoc vocabs but I'm more interested in vocabs that are actually standardized or supported by something
Seirdy: not exactly on point, but https://www.w3.org/TR/dpub-aria-1.1/ may be of interest

content.body: What exactly is the abbr attribute on the TH element used for? The only example I've found (on the W3Schools site) just shows it being placed in the TH tag, but does not describe what you would do with it. It seems to only be useful as informational to anyone viewing the page source.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: What exactly is the abbr attribute on the TH element used for? The only example I've found (on the W3Schools site) just shows it being placed in the TH tag, but does not describe what you would do with it. It seems to only be useful as informational to anyone viewing the page source.

content.body:
> <@wayneca:matrix.org> What exactly is the abbr attribute on the TH element used for? The only example I've found (on the W3Schools site) just shows it being placed in the TH tag, but does not describe what you would do with it. It seems to only be useful as informational to anyone viewing the page source.

"informational to anyone viewing the page source" is approximately right. There are many features in HTML like this, e.g. the distinction between <section> and <article>, <q>'s cite="" attribute, all of microdata, etc. With the caveat that "viewing the page source" might be something a non-browser tool is doing (especially for the microdata example), and such tools might do something that eventually is useful to users.

content.body: I see. Thanks for the explanation. Because I don't typically delve that far into the behind the scenes part of web-browsing I don't usually think of these things. I just want to make sure my understanding is correct as I build my list of attributes and what they do.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I see. Thanks for the explanation. Because I don't typically delve that far into the behind the scenes part of web-browsing I don't usually think of these things. content.body: The html5 specification shows autofocus being a global attribute (it says HTML elements, but W3Schools lists those as being Global Attributes), but the W3Schools site lists autofocus as belonging to <button>, <input>, <select>, <textarea>. Is it global or is it specific to only these tags?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: The html5 specification shows autofocus being a global attribute (it says HTML elements, but W3Schools lists those as being Global Attributes), but the W3Schools site lists autofocus as belonging to <button>, <input>, <select>, <textarea>. Is it global or is it specific to only these tags?

content.body: wayneca: W3Schools is not an authoritative source of information (it also doesn't belong to the W3C)
content.formatted_body: wayneca: W3Schools is not an authoritative source of information (it also doesn't belong to the W3C)

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: wayneca: W3Schools is not an authoritative source of information (it also doesn't belong to the W3C)
wayneca: W3Schools is not an authoritative source of information (it also doesn't belong to the W3C)

content.body: OK. I just use it because it has much information in one place that is more easily digested than the specification is. It also agrees with the specification in many things. I have noticed that there are some things in the specification that are absent in the W3Schools information. Based on this response I will take the specification as being correct when W3Schools shows something different.
